properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm with higher amounts possible in some areas, especially over the Avalon Peninsula. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h except possibly up to 100 km/h over exposed areas. Locations: Avalon and Burin Peninsulas and Clarenville and vicinity. Time span: Tuesday evening until Wednesday evening. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop late in the day Tuesday, and will then become accompanied by strong northerly winds and reduced visibility in blowing snow early Wednesday morning. Snow will become lighter Wednesday afternoon but strengthening winds will continue to produce blowing snow until Wednesday evening. At this time there is some uncertainty regarding where the highest snowfall amounts will occur. Additional information will be provided as details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-23T23:52:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-23T07:53:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4222527373.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm with higher amounts possible in some areas. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h except possibly up to 100 km/h over exposed areas. Locations: the Avalon and Burin Peninsulas. Time span: Tuesday evening until Wednesday evening. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop late in the day Tuesday, and will then become accompanied by strong northerly winds and reduced visibility in blowing snow early Wednesday morning. Snow will become lighter Wednesday afternoon but strong winds will continue to produce blowing snow until Wednesday evening. At this time there is some uncertainty regarding where the highest snowfall amounts will occur. Additional information will be provided as details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm with higher amounts possible in some areas, especially over the Avalon Peninsula. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h except possibly up to 100 km/h over exposed areas. Locations: Avalon, Burin, Connaigre and Bonavista Peninsulas as well as Clarenville and vicinity. Time span: Tuesday evening until Wednesday evening. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop late in the day Tuesday and become heavy, at times, Tuesday night. The snow will become accompanied by strong northerly winds and reduced visibility in blowing snow early Wednesday morning. Snow will become lighter Wednesday afternoon but strengthening winds will continue to produce blowing snow until Wednesday evening. At this time there is some uncertainty regarding where the highest snowfall amounts will occur. Additional information will be provided as details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR SMITHERS AND VERNON The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has continued a Road Dust Advisory because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-03-23T22:21:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-03-23T06:22:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2213575964.2020
Area: North Okanagan, Bulkley Valley

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm continues. Heavy snow is falling over parts of the McGregor region early this morning. Snowfall accumulation totalling 10 to 15 cm is expected by midday before the snow tapers to flurries. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-23T21:14:12-00:00

Area: McGregor
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm continues. Snow continues today with a further 5 to 10 cm of snow by this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this morning. Flurries, heavy at times, will give some additional local amounts of 2 to 4 centimetres this morning before ending late this morning. Travel is expected to be hazardous at times due to local snowfall accumulation. Quickly changing and deteriorating travel conditions are expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-23T19:59:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-23T13:07:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0425733439.2020
Area: Marathon - Schreiber
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, rain and wind on Tuesday. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm with more possible. Total rainfall: 10 to 25 mm with more possible. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 40 to 60 km/h. Location: Nova Scotia. Time span: Tuesday morning until Tuesday evening. Remarks: Snow will start Tuesday morning and then change to rain by late morning or afternoon over mainland Nova Scotia. The snow will mix with rain in the afternoon over southern Cape Breton. Over northern Cape Breton and portions of northern Nova Scotia the snow will persist into the evening. Along the Atlantic coast rainfall amounts of up to 25 mm are likely but higher amounts are possible. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are generally expected however a slight change in track could give higher amounts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-24T05:30:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-23T13:31:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3813233847.2020

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High southwest winds reaching 90 kilometres per hour are currently blowing over this region. Winds will diminish in the morning. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-23T20:49:52-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Snow will continue to push into Alberta this morning as a low pressure system develops in central Alberta. Snow will fall throughout the day today, before finally tapering off early Tuesday morning. For the Whitecourt region, areas north of Whitecourt are expected to receive snowfall totals of 10 to 15 cm whereas areas to the south, are not expected to receive such high totals. This warning may need to be expanded to other regions as the system continues to develop. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-24T02:31:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-23T10:32:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2512827820.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A disturbance forecast to develop over southern Alberta today will spread snow across the northern grainbelt of Saskatchewan tonight. Total snowfall amounts of 10 cm are possible over the area before tapering off late Tuesday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
